summary:
Currently working for the European field- and reliability aftermarket engineering team facilitating and executing so-called 'level 3 root cause analyses' for centrifugal pumps and mechanical seals.

Main experience in developing, engineering and testing high end sealing solutions for nuclear related applications. Experience in developing custom made pump upgrade solutions for the European nuclear industry related to both applications on the nuclear island and Balance of Plant.

Specialties: 
1. Sealing solutions for ultra-pure water applications, both nuclear and fossil power
2. Sealing solutions for reactor coolant pumps (PWR) and reactor recirculation pumps (BWR)
3. Sealing solutions for nuclear and fossil feed water pumps
4. Strong focus on pump and seal system related interaction

projects.title: Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on drainage pumps in the Netherlands
projects.description: A local waterboard had installed new drainage pumps back in 2016. After a few years of service and only 4000 - 5000 running hours a visual inspection revealed suspected wear of the water lubricated marine bearings in the bottom of the pump. An investigation was requested by the waterboard what to do with the current bearings.

projects.title: Improving the sealing reliability of pumps in a steam dump control system
projects.description:
A pressurized water reactor owner faced multiple sealing failures in their steam dump control system on the turbine side (non-nuclear balance of plant). The commodity type sealing solution applied in the pumps of this specific system uses a specific gland design with four 'fingers' for tightening the gland against the pump cover. 

In case of a reactor scram, a limited percentage of the total steam volume created in the steam generators is dumped into a large tank filled with cold demineralized feed water. This dumping of steam is an extremely violent process, whereby the pumps downstream of this tank, face significant waterhammer and pressure pulsations. Estimations are that the additional pressure may be 30 bar or more. These pressure spikes cause the fingers of the original seal gland to simply snap off and the seal to prematurely fail.

A new sealing solution was proposed using a normal full traditional seal gland with holes, designed for peak pressures up to 80 bar. Besides an upgraded seal design, also the seal plan was massively improved going from a seal plan 21 to a seal plan 23. The pumped feed water has a normal temperature of 160 °C with a sealing pressure of approx. 28 bar.

projects.title: Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on offshore reciprocating pumps used for oil well stimulation
projects.description: Two offshore installed reciprocating pumps handling sea water up to 400 bar pressure off the coast of Poland showed a number of different reliability problems associated with fatigue cracks and material overload of different crucial components. An RCA was performed on the check valves, cylinder block, plungers and cord packing seals with various reliability improvements being implemented.

projects.title: Developing a reliable mechanical seal for use in low speed, high flow cooling water pumps
projects.description: This project dealt with designing a mechanical seal solution to solve corrosion and unreliable performance of competitor mechanical seals for a Swedish nuclear power station. As sea water sitting in stagnant areas can become aggressive due to lack of oxygen, more exotic type alloys might be required to withstand a specific form of corrosion. The Pitting Resistance Equivalent Number (PREN) for the alloys to be applied has be sufficiently high to prevent corrosion. In this case 316Ti was replaced with Superduplex metal parts. And in order to ensure the seal faces would be lubricated during the initial start of the pump where the water column needs to build inside the pump special provisions were made to keep the seal faces flooded at all times. Currently, the new Allpac type mechanical seals are meeting the 6 year maintenance intervals, which coincides with the maintenance work done on the cooling water pumps. Given the excellent results, similar mechanical seals have now been installed on the main cooling water pumps in other Swedish and Finnish nuclear power plants.

projects.title: Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on an anti-vortex cover plate used at a drainage station in the Netherlands
projects.description: A high capacity drainage station in the north of the Netherlands had undergone a pump capacity increase in 2007 increasing flow from 800 to 1400 cubic meters/minute. As a result of this large flow increase, free surface vortices started to develop around a flow of 1100 cubic meters/minute, requiring the use of a cover plate at pump suction intake. The cover plate made from high density polyethylene failed twice and even blocked pump suction, which starved the pump. A root cause analysis was requested by the local waterboard to examine the situation and propose alternatives for the design of the installed cover plate.

projects.title: Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on a radial bearing of a vertical Essential Service Water pump
projects.description: A nuclear power station based on the pressurized water reactor design principle has four essential service water pumps installed for providing cooling water to the nuclear island. These safety related pumps are monitored by the nuclear authorities as they have a critical safety function during operation and shut down of the power station. One pump showed radial bearing damage, which was never seen before and a request was made by the power station to conduct a root cause analysis on why the bearing failed.

projects.title: Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on a broken impeller hub wear ring on a crude oil charging pump
projects.description: One of total six crude oil charging pumps on a refinery in the Netherlands suffered from a broken impeller hub wear ring following a recent refurbishment. The wear ring chiseled its way into the impeller until the wheel was severed from the hub and pump flow was drastically affected. A root cause analysis was made involving material examination and validation of design to estimate the risk associated with the remaining five pumps in operation.

projects.title: Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on a bearing housing oil leakage problem of a high energy reactor feed water pump
projects.description:
Problem description:
One of the world's largest nuclear BWR power stations conducted a power uprate, whereby the existing reactor feed water pumps underwent a complete overhaul with fitting new hydraulics. After plant restart, one of the three reactor feed water pumps was showing an oil leakage on the drive end side bearing housing facing the drive coupling. The other two feed pumps continued working fine. Several attempts (trial and error) were conducted in trying to stop the oil leakage, but without result. 
In December 2019, a root cause analysis team was formed to investigate the problem. Not any easy task given the lack of equipment access once the power plant is under steam.

Outcome RCA:
Following on-site measurements, the culprit for the oil leakage was identified and recommendations were made to the end user. At present, this power plant is back to full load operation without suffering from oil leakages on this particular reactor feed water pump. The problem has been solved according to the power plant owners.

projects.title: Seal face generated electro-corrosion on mechanical seal faces in high speed BWR reactor feed water pumps
projects.description:
Investigating and researching the phenomenon of self induced electro corrosion in mechanical seals used in high speed feed water pumps handling ultra-pure water for nuclear and fossil power stations (technology mainly applied in boiling water reactors and combined water treatment conventional power plants).

In August 2014, a first of a kind sealing concept was installed on one of three reactor feed water pumps in a large Swedish nuclear BWR plant using a rotating seal face applying a tantalum coating in combination with Precision Face Topography (wavy face). In August 2015, these special seals were removed and showed that the tantalum coating could survive the electro corrosion observed in reactor water feed water pumps. One rotating seal face was in good condition, but the second rotating seal face was damaged. 
A detailed examination later on confirmed that the quality of the CVD made tantalum coating was below standard in the sense that the coating was not uniform, causing the electro corrosion to eat into the SiC base material underneath. Two spare mechanical seals with the identical tantalum coated rotating seal faces were installed and the pump was successfully taken back into service. 
An inspection in December 2017 of the non-drive end seal showed that its tantalum coated rotating seal face was in pristine condition, proving that the solution actually holds up in feed water used in a boiling water reactor.

The remaining two reactor feed water pumps have also been converted to the new sealing solution. To date, all six mechanical seals are working flawlessly. On top of that, a second BWR nuclear plant in Finland also installed the same sealing concept back in May 2021 and the results in comparison to the original sealing solution have been excellent. Average sealing temperatures are 10 °C lower without any visible leakages. The research project has been closed.

projects.title: Essential service water pump suction intake solution
projects.description:
Project description:
Four existing nuclear pressurized water reactors use twelve essential service water pumps for crucial cooling of their (safety related) equipment on the nuclear island. The water level of the river, which is used as their ultimate heat sink, has been dropping consistently over the years and is predicted to reach lower levels, whereby special pumping measures have to be applied for these power plants to ensure sufficient cooling water. The special pumping measures are very time consuming and costly. A request was made by the owner of the power plant to investigate a new suction intake solution for the existing essential service water pumps, allowing these pumps to take in cooling water at a 0.5 meter lowers than the current limit which has been set.

Status:
A detailed engineering study was made involving computational fluid dynamics with the outcome presented to the owner. A first proposal was submitted. The owner is currently studying the different options.

projects.title: Improving sealing solution for a gas cooling water pump at a Finnish waste-to-energy power plant
projects.description:
Project description:
This particular power plant 100 km north of Helsinki installed 2 Flowserve high pressure water pumps for controlling the temperatures of the gas inside the incinerator as part of a new waste-to-energy concept developed by Valmet. Originally, the pumps were fitted with single Flowserve DHTW high pressure pusher type seals, but their reliability was poor, also because the seals were simply selected during the OEM Project phase from a sales catalogue without prior lab testing or indepth engineering analysis of the seal's design. The barrel type pumps handle 300 C hot water at a suction pressure of 145 bar and have a discharge pressure of 155 bar. Sealing pressure is 145 bar using a seal plan 23. Seal failures would show sudden explosions of high pressure steam clouds and hot water. In order to protect operation and maintenance personnel a provisional wall of steel sheet plating was erected. Frequent seal failures lead to high cost in repairs and the end user was requesting improvements in mechanical seal reliability.

Project approach and solution:
A site visit was made in June 2016 to the power plant to view the situation firsthand and get the latest operating data from the end user. It was noticed that the seal cooling capacity was undersized (as is often is the case in such OEM projects), but also that the combination of sealing hot water at 145 bar pressure with a relative low speed (2070 - 2400 - 2680 RPM) requires a thorough review of the seal's design. A proposal was made for an improved seal design including extra safety features and increased seal cooling, which was accepted by the end user. Laboratory testing under real operating conditions was included to provide the optimum guarantee for the end user.

Project status:
The new, optimized mechanical seal design is currently under laboratory testing and new, larger capacity seal coolers have been supplied. Finally, also the interconnecting seal piping documentation was modified.

projects.title: Engineering preparations for replacement of a gearbox used in boric acid injection pump trains
projects.description:
In relation to a Long Term Operation (LTO) project at a European PWR nuclear power plant, a request was made to replace existing planetary gearboxes with a new gearbox design for (2x3) pump trains used for boric acid injection service. 
The two PWR plants, which were constructed pre-ASME era, use triplex piston pumps connected to a gearbox, which in turn is connected to a fluid drive coupling and an electric motor. The original gearbox manufacturer was no longer on the market and reversed engineered parts did not provide reliable performance.
In order to facilitate a formal Request for Quotation (RFQ) the end user needed a Certificate of Conformity from the Pump Manufacturer stating that the new replacement gearbox meets the original pump design criteria and will work correctly once put into service. Such a certificate can only be supplied after rigerous engineering checks and analyses are made on the new hardware as well as the existing hardware.

Project status:
Engineering as well as the actual delivery of new gearboxes has been completed, including the delivery of the certificate of conformity. Both nuclear plants are back in operation.

projects.title: Destaging existing emergency feed water pumps for a European PWR nuclear power plant
projects.description:
Project description:
A European PWR nuclear power plant has 4 existing emergency feed water pumps. Following the consequences after the Fukushima nuclear accident, nuclear power plants are reinforcing their operating scenarios in case of an emergency situation. A request was made if the 4 feed water pumps, using 12 impellers per pump, could be modified to achieve a lower head, while still achieving a minimum guaranteed operating point on their curve. Hydraulic engineering showed that by removing 2 impellers the new duty point could be achieved. This is known as destaging where an impeller is removed and a flow guide bushing and sleeve assure low losses inside the pump. A lateral critical analysis would have to show, which impellers would be best to remove in terms of rotor stability.

Project status:
Order was received for 4 new destaged pump rotors and modifying one spare pump rotor. Project completion achieved in Q3 2018. Destaged emergency feed water pumps have been taken back into service meeting end user expectations.

projects.title: Upgrading existing gear type couplings to flexible membrane couplings on steam generator feed water pumps of an European PWR nuclear power plant
projects.description:
Project description:
This end user has three steam generator feed water pumps operating since 1981 using oil lubricated gear type couplings between the feed water pump and gearbox. Pumps are all electric motor driven. Gear couplings can be sensitive for wear if the setting is not accurate and the oil lubrication sometimes can become a housekeeping issue due to oil leakages. Use of flexible membrane couplings today is standard practice and removes these gear coupling concerns. Of course, changing from a heavy gear coupling to a lighter flexible membrane coupling changes the pump rotor behaviour and a check is necessary assuring vibrations do not increase due to a modified rotor stability. A lateral critical analysis and torsional analysis are mandatory checks to safeguard future pump operation.

Project status:
The engineering calculations were conducted and the feed water pumps were fitted with new light weight drive couplings. The power station is back in operation.

projects.title: Supporting a standardization project of anti-electro corrosion mechanical seals on large (fossil) boiler feed water pumps
projects.description:
Project description:
Supporting the Seal Project Sales and OEM Engineering organization with a standardization project for a global pump competitor manufacturing large boiler feed water pumps with the latest anti electro corrosion sealing technology developed between 2005 and 2012. Provided support in the form of actual presentation at the headquarters of the pump OEM, as well as supporting evidence in the form of published papers, testimonies from end users and detailed discussions. This project is considered a breakthrough in the Power Market industry since it removed the blacklisting applied by this pump OEM on the potential use of Flowserve mechanical seals for this specific pump service.

Status:
The seal standardization project for this original equipment manufacturer was completed and very specific technical guidelines were released for seal design engineers to use for future applications.

projects.title: Conduct a Root Cause Analysis (RCA) concerning a critical bearing failure on a safety related centrifugal pump
projects.description:
A European PWR is using a total of six so-called shutdown pumps. These pumps are also known as residual heat removal pumps and are combined with low head safety injection service. These 260 kW end suction type pumps normally only operate when the nuclear reactor is shutdown providing cooling to remove residual heat from the fuel in the reactor vessel. Their second function is referred to as low head safety injection. 

Problem description:
In 2006 and recently in 2015, bearing cages of the axial thrust bearing were found broken after only a few hundred hours of operation. RCA support was requested what may cause the problem.

Problem approach:
An engineering study conducted by the bearing supplier hinted that bearing cage damages to the outer bearing of an angular contact bearings put in an O-type setting are typically the result of parasitic radial forces resulting from increased tolerances of the individual pump parts. Also, historical files showed that the bearing fitted were fitted with a larger internal play (type CC), while these days such a pump would be fitted with normal internal bearing play (type CB). Fitting a CB bearing instead of a CC bearing does mean an official change in the pump's design for which nuclear regulatory approval needs to be sought. On request of the end user a detailed plan was prepared that showed a combination of theoretical studies and practical testing to demonstrate that this change in bearing play would be possible and safe to conduct.

Solution applied:
A thermal finite element calculation using a 3D model of the pump with an analysis at normal room temperature, as well as LOCA condition verifying thermal expansion of the different pump parts justifying that the installation of a CB type bearing is possible.

Status:
The first CB type bearing was installed during the 2018 outage, but today all other pumps have been converted as well. The bearing problem is considered solved by the owner of the nuclear plants.

projects.title: Improving seal cooling capacity at Avedore-2 power station in Denmark and Millmerran power station in Australia
projects.description:
Description:
While both power stations are individual case histories, they are linked by the fact that in many Original Equipment Manufacturing deliveries cooling for the mechanical seals on critical boiler feed water pumps are often regarded as a closing post in the contract negotiations. During the OEM and Project stage, End user/Owners and Contractors often have a common goal to keep the capital expenditure (CAPEX) as low as possible while assuring future functionality and reliability of the power station. This is sometimes conflicting and can lead to selections of hardware by the OEM Suppliers which in reality fall short of their goal. Contractual requirements often have a limited time restriction before the warranties run out, while power plants have a 40 to 60 year operation window set during which this critical equipment should function in a reliable manner. Mechanical seal selection, but more prominently the crucial cooling system for the mechanical seals are an example of such hardware. 
In both power plants mechanical seal reliability on the main turbo feed water pump was low caused by relatively high seal operating temperatures and low margins when seal leakage increased due to wear.

Solution applied:
Remove the existing seal plan 23 system completely and replace it with new larger diameter tubing based piping system. Install a Graham Heliflow type seal cooler with more than 3.5 times the cooling capacity of the old seal cooler. Ensure interconnecting piping has a continuous upslope to allow regular sparingly venting of the system.

Project status:
Both power plants are today operating with significant lower seal loop temperatures, which will improve overall mechanical seal reliability. More seal coolers have been purchased for the second power unit at Milmerran PS.

projects.title: Resolving black lubrication oil problems and gasket leakage on two heater drain pumps
projects.description:
Problem description:
A European PWR nuclear power plant bought 2 additional heater drain pumps in 2008. One of the pumps showed black coloured lubrication oil with copper particles found in the oil sump. The damage appeared to come from the oil rings installed inside the bearing housing which splash oil inside the bearing housing for lubricating the ball bearings. The second pump would show hardened elastomer O-rings around the suction area of the pump. As both pumps were out of warranty, the end user requested a solution for these problems.

Solution approach:
For both subjects a solutions matrix was developed with solutions ranging from good - better - best. This to present all options to the customer and have their input during the selection process. A decision was made to make changes that would seem effective and not too intrusive and complex.

Solution applied:
Design two new journal sleeves with guiding chamfers and two new trapezoidal shaped oil rings without ID grooves and a deeper submergence into the oil bath (shaft diameter is different on both sides of the pump).
For the elastomers, after deliberation with the original elastomer manufacturer, is to use a Perfluoroelastomer material suitable for use in hot water and steam, but only to replace those O-rings near the pump suction part as these appeared to be suffering the most. The end user suspects that this problem is related to a plant system design problem where steam may form at pump suction under specific operating conditions, as similar damage has been seen in another PWR plant using different heater drain pumps.

Status:
New oil rings and journal sleeves have been installed, next to the Perfluorelastomer O-rings during 2018 outage. The owner of the power plant will also check and verify if both pumps are indeed installed level as they should be.

projects.title: Solving pump startup problems at a Spanish petrochemical installation
projects.description: This projects deals with the use of proprietary Precision Face Topography applied in a dual pressurized mechanical seal, to solve the operational problems related to high start-up torques in a high pressure pump handling light hydrocarbons.  The specifics of this project dealt with finding the right balance of applying seal face topography using specific laser-machined micro features to solve the operational problems for the refinery operators related to the high start-up torque, whilst ensuring that the overall seal leakage rate was kept at an acceptable level.

projects.title: Root Cause Analysis (RCA) Oil Pipeline Sakhalin Island
projects.description:
Problem description:
A global oil company has a platform off the East Coast of Sakhalin Island and uses two crude oil pipeline pumps to pump the oil to a processing unit on Sakhalin Island where it can be processed. From here the processed oil is transported to loading facility in the south of Sakhalin Island for shipping the oil across the globe. The pumps are competitor pumps, multistage, axial split, between bearings, API type BB3. They have been fitted with dual pressurized mechanical seals using seal plan 53B, but these seals regularly fail. Repairs are conducted locally due to remoteness of this location. End user is requesting RCA input into the mechanical seal problems.

RCA approach:
All seal inspection reports made during each repair were studied. All the individual seal failures were noted and tallied showing that the largest cause for failure was the same. All mechanical seals are lubricated by an independant and monitored sealant system. It uses a water-glycol barrier fluid due to the cold ambient conditions and any contamination of a dual pressurized seal with crude oil means that reversed pressure from the pipeline system must have occurred pushing the unprocessed crude into the seal and sealant system.

Solution proposed:
Recommended a WANDA hydraulic study of the pipeline from the pumps on the platform till the onshore processing unit to examine the hydraulic conditions during pumping and transients. It is suspected that rapid closure of a valve downstream of the platform, may cause a pressure spike in the system pushing the oil into the mechanical seal. Broken silicon carbide seal faces on the product side, which would become pressurized from the inside when subjected to a reversed pressure condtion, seem to subscribe to this root cause.

Status:
Recommendation was given to the oil company, but no hydraulic study has been performed yet.

profile_positions.description:
Responsible for providing technical support to nuclear end user customers concerning existing centrifugal pumps and their mechanical seals, as well as selection of new original equipment in system upgrade projects. Besides working for mainly European customers, I also occasionally assist with helping US and Asian customers and colleagues. This support entails equipment used in the primary loop (Code equipment), as well as safety related equipment and also non-safety related equipment.

One task is to provide support for BWR (boiling water reactor) and PWR (pressurized water reactor ) systems concerning their primary coolant pumps and their mechanical seals, also referred to as reactor recirculation pumps and reactor coolant pumps. This support is typically engineering related aimed at answering technical questions or providing operational guidance. However, it may also include on-site inspection of used parts in the 'hot workshop' of a nuclear installation or assist in different types of root cause analysis (RCA) problems.

Besides nuclear power related work, my focus is also on fossil power generation, as well as providing assistance to the Aftermarket Sales and Commercial Operations department with the more complex refinery (up- and downstream), petrochemical, pipeline or general industry type of applications.
